Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 41661  
January 2008 
 
 
 
Islamic Republic of Pakistan: Competitiveness and 
Structural Transformation in Pakistan
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 14 January 2008) 
 
Currency Unit –  Pakistan rupee/s (PRe/PRs) 
PRe1.00 =  $0.0159362550 
$1.00 =  PRs62.75

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Law, economic management and public policy  
Subsector  –  Economic management  
Theme  –  Sustainable Economic Growth  
Subtheme  –  Promoting macroeconomic stability 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Vice President  L. Jin, Vice President Operations 1 
Director General  J. Miranda, Central and West Asia Department (CWRD) 
Director  R. Y. Siy, Jr., Country Coordination and Regional Cooperation Division, 
CWRD 
   
Team leader  J. Felipe, Principal Economist, CWRD 
Team member  N. Usui, Economist, CWRD

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The successful Asian economies—the newly industrialized economies of Malaysia and 
Thailand, and, more recently, the People’s Republic of China (PRC) and Viet Nam—have 
changed in two key ways over the past three decades. They are not only significantly bigger, 
they are also significantly different. What sets the successful Asian economies apart, beyond 
their high growth rates, is their rapid, intense structural transformation. Their forms of output and 
employment have been dramatically altered. Resources have moved from agriculture into high 
value-added sectors in industry and services. Production has diversified, and firms have learned 
how to manufacture and export a more sophisticated and technologically advanced range of 
products. Labor productivity in these nations has grown rapidly.  
 
2.  Analysis of the extent and depth of structural transformation of Pakistan’s economy 
might provide an answer to this question. Growth and structural transformation are directly 
related. Countries do not grow by simply reproducing themselves on a larger scale. Generally—
unless all sectors expand at identical rates—economies change as they grow, in terms what 
they produce as well how they produce it. They use different inputs, including new methods of 
production. The successful economies have generated new activities that are characterized by 
higher productivity and increasing returns to scale. The transitions to these new patterns of 
production  and  specialization  involve  upgrading  within  each  sector  to  higher  value-added 
activities through the introduction of new products and processes. These changes entail far-
reaching transformations in many areas, such as the skill content of output. Countries that can 
sustain these multiple transitions across the different stages of their structural transformation will 
grow successfully. This technical assistance (TA)1 will analyze Pakistan’s growth prospects for 
the next decade from the point of view of this kind of structural transformation. 
 
3.  Except for economies well-endowed with natural resources, prosperity is the result of 
cumulative economic change. Ultimately, structural transformation is about the transformation of 
the  economy  with  a  view  to  (i)  transferring  resources  to  higher  value-added  sectors,  (ii) 
diversifying production while upgrading it, and (iii) producing and exporting a more sophisticated 
range  of  products.  This  entails:  (i)  identifying  the  products  that  the  country  can  produce 
profitably by using its capabilities, (ii) using new inputs and methods of production, and (iii) 
exploring new activities and developing new capabilities. The key to structural transformation is 
industrialization, a process that requires purposeful action. 
 
4.  A Fact-Finding Mission was undertaken in August 2007. As part of this mission, a 
background paper on structural transformation in Pakistan was written and presented to the 
Pakistan Institute of Development Economics (PIDE), Government’s Planning Commission, and 
the Planning and Development Board of the Punjab provincial government. Discussions were 
also held with the special secretary of finance, and the deputy secretary of the Ministry of 
Economic Affairs and Statistics. These presentations strengthened the rationale underlying the 
TA, and alerted policy makers in Pakistan to the relevance of the subject.  
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
5.  Although Pakistan has outpaced many other countries in the world economically, its 
growth falls short of the rates achieved by East and Southeast Asian nations in the last 30 
years—and lags growth in the PRC and Viet Nam more recently. During the last four decades, 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 13 November 2007.

2   
Pakistan has grown on average slightly more than 5% a year, including frequent boom and bust 
episodes (Figure 1). Since the mid-1960s, Pakistan has had fewer—and comparatively less 
intense—periods  of  rapid  growth  than  PRC  and  such  newly  industrialized  countries  as 
Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand. The Lao People’s Democratic Republic and Viet Nam have 
had almost as many bouts of rapid growth as Pakistan—in only about half the time. 2

prepared by State Bank of Pakistan and latest Economic Survey 2006–07 of the Government of 
Pakistan’s Ministry of Finance. The trend growth was estimated using the Hodrick-Prescott filter 
with a smoothing parameter of 50. 
 
 
6.  However, since the FY2001, when it was slightly below 2.0%, Pakistan’s growth has 
accelerated. In FY2005, its growth rate reached 9.0%, followed by 6.6% in FY2006 and 7.0% in 
FY2007. The average growth rate in 2002–2007 was 6.3%. Further, growth has been trending 
up recently—since the 1960s, 3 of the 9 years in which growth was 7.0% or more were in 2004, 
2005, and 2007 (Figure 1). Some evidence suggests structural change as well. Historically, 
private consumption has driven growth in the country, but in fiscal year July 2006 to June 2007 
investment was the largest contributor to the increase in output. A key question among policy 
makers now is whether Pakistan will be able to sustain these improvements.  
 
7.  Pakistan’s transformation during the last three decades has not been as fast and as 
intense as that of the successful Asian economies. A recent analysis of Pakistan’s structural 
transformation during this period (footnote 1) included these main findings:  
 
(i)  The output growth rates of industry and services are significantly higher than that 
of agriculture. Given the service sector’s high share in output, services account 
for more than 50% of the total output growth rate. The contributions of agriculture 
and industry are significantly smaller. The service sector also accounts for the 
largest share of total labor productivity growth.  
(ii)  Pakistan is a service economy from the point of view of its output structure, but 
an agricultural economy from the point of view of employment.  
(iii)  Labor productivity growth within economic sectors has contributed substantially 
more  to  overall  labor  productivity  growth  than  reallocation  of  labor  from 
                                                 
2  Felipe, Jesus. 2007. Competitiveness and Structural Transformation in Pakistan. Manila (manuscript).

3
agriculture into the other two sectors. Such reallocation plays a minor role 
overall. Reallocation of labor from agriculture into services has been much 
more important than that from agriculture into industry.  
(iv)  Labor absorption in Pakistan has declined because the absorption capacity of 
the  service  sector  is  insufficient  to  compensate  for  the  falling  capacity  of 
agriculture, and the stagnation of industry. 
(v)  Pakistan’s manufacturing share is not low, given its income per capita, trade ratio 
in gross domestic product (GDP), and population. However, the share of this 
sector in total output has been stagnant since the 1970s. This contrasts with 
what has occurred in Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand, for example, where this 
sector’s shares increased.  
(vi)  The manufacturing sector is heavily concentrated in food and beverages, and in 
textiles. Together, they account for close to half of the sector’s value-added. 
(vii)  The  level  of  technology  in  Pakistan’s  manufacturing  sector  is  relatively  low, 
compared with those in other Asian countries. Moreover, the share of high-
technology products within manufacturing value-added is also low, and has been 
stagnant for 40 years. 
(viii)  Pakistan’s level of labor productivity has increased very slowly since the 1970s, 
leaving plenty of room for it to catch up with the developed world. 
(ix)  The  share  of  the  top  10  exports  in  Pakistan’s  export  total  has  dropped 
significantly  in  the  last  two  decades.  Nevertheless,  the  share  of  textiles  still 
dominates the top ten exports. The weighted average of the per capita GDPs of 
the countries that also export Pakistan’s top 10 exports has declined significantly. 
This indicates that Pakistan is stuck in exports that are also being produced by 
countries that are becoming relatively poorer. In addition, the income level of 
Pakistan’s  exports,  a  proxy  for  the  country’s  export  complexity  and 
competitiveness, has not increased in two decades. 
 
8.  If Pakistan is to maintain, and even increase, its growth rate, it needs to accelerate its 
structural transformation and improvements in the quality and diversification of its exports. The 
TA will produce four analytical papers that will examine the following questions:  
 
(i)  What information is needed to assess completely where Pakistan’s structural 
transformation stands, and what are the possibilities for upgrading the country’s 
production structure?  
(ii)  What institutional framework and policies should Pakistan’s policy makers design 
and implement to ensure the successful transformation of its economy and rapid 
growth, and how should this process be conceptualized and undertaken?   
(iii)  How  are  the  sectoral  imbalances  and  reallocation  of  labor  that  structural 
transformation entails to be managed? 
(iv)  How can Pakistan design a plan for structural transformation? 
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  Pakistan’s objective is to maintain or increase its current economic growth rates—7.5% 
over  the  past  four  years—well  into  the  future.  To  help  Pakistan’s  policy  makers  and 
entrepreneurs better understand the importance of structural transformation in achieving this 
goal, and to illustrate what it will take to make current growth sustainable, the country’s potential

4   
for structural transformation needs to be examined. The analysis will also improve the Asian 
Development Bank’s (ADB) policy advice to the Government of Pakistan (the Government). This 
TA will (i) explain the causes of slow structural transformation of Pakistan’s economy; (ii) 
prepare four analytical papers on structural transformation in Pakistan; (iii) work closely with the 
Government, policy makers, and entrepreneurs to guarantee that the results of this TA are 
internalized;  (iv)  make  policy  recommendations;  and  (v)  disseminate  the  findings  through 
seminars and publications. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA consists of four components. The first paper will provide an assessment of 
Pakistan’s economic structure—in terms of what a country produces and how it does it. This is 
called  the  “product  space.”  A  rapid  upward  trajectory  depends  on  a  country  moving  into 
activities that create productivity gains; and, when these are exhausted, shifting again to newer 
activities that are even more productive. Recent research shows that it is possible to graph or 
map  what  a  country  produces  and  how  closely  this  basket  matches  what  other  countries 
produce. In this way, the possibilities open to Pakistan to diversify production and increase 
productivity can be analyzed in light of its technological and social capabilities. The analysis will 
assess Pakistan vis-à-vis other countries in Asia.  
 
11.  A second paper will examine the quality and sophistication of Pakistan’s exports. A 
strong empirical relationship exists between a recently developed measure of a country’s export 
sophistication and that country’s level of income. This relationship suggests that, as countries 
develop, they change their export package. The measure also reflects structural transformation. 
An in-depth and detailed analysis of Pakistan’s export structure will provide key information for 
assessing the speed and direction of its transformation, and for comparisons with other Asian 
countries. 
 
12.   The third paper is a diagnostics analysis of the impediments to structural transformation 
in Pakistan. Structural transformation does not come naturally; rather, it must be induced by 
policy. The question is: how? Most often reform is required, either to facilitate the transfer of 
resources across sectors, to develop new activities, or to increase competition. This raises the 
next question: which reform will deliver the most benefit? The purpose of this growth diagnostics 
exercise is to pinpoint where a little reform can go a long way. 
 
13.  The fourth paper will employ the output of the previous three to propose a plan for 
industrial development in Pakistan, based on the belief that structural transformation is not 
automatic but must be induced through policy. 
 
14.  The study results will be widely disseminated in Pakistan. To address concerns about 
how  the  legal  and  policy  environment  in  Pakistan  may  affect  the  development  and 
implementation of a realistic industrialization plan, consultants and team members will work 
closely with the Government’s Planning Commission. They will also make presentations to the 
three main stakeholders—the Government, policy makers, and entrepreneurs. Each group plays 
a different and important role. The Government must demonstrate the political will to undertake 
structural transformation, policy makers must take part in designing the plan, and entrepreneurs 
will be responsible for carrying it out effectively. Ultimately, the success of the TA depends on 
whether the stakeholders internalize its key ideas. The terms of reference are in Appendix 3.

5
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $370,000 equivalent.  The Government has 
requested ADB to finance $350,000 equivalent.  The TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s TA funding program. The Government will finance the balance of the TA cost through in-
kind contributions.  Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The Planning Commission will be the Executing Agency responsible for implementing 
and monitoring the TA.  The study is expected to be completed in 18 months, by September 
2009. A team of international consultants will be recruited. The work will require about 36 
person-months of international consulting. 
  
17.  Given the nature of the project and the expertise required, the Center for International 
Development (CID) at Harvard University has been identified as the most suitable consultant. 
Much of the TA will follow methodologies and techniques developed by CID; CID software will 
also be used. CID, as part of the John F. Kennedy School of Government, Harvard University, is 
a leading development institution. In the past few years, researchers at CID have developed 
novel techniques to analyze a country’s development challenges by determining its binding 
constraints, and by graphing the country’s product space. 3 CID draws upon faculty, staff, and 
researchers  from  many  schools  and  departments  at  Harvard,  which  gives  it  a  valuable 
multidisciplinary character. For this reason, ADB will recruit the services of CID according to the 
single-source selection method in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2007, as amended from time to time). 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $350,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Pakistan for Competitiveness and Structural Transformation in Pakistan, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                 
3  ADB’s Economics and Research Department has advocated the application of the growth diagnostics methodology 
of CID in country strategy formulation.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) project, Competitiveness and Structural Transformation in 
Pakistan, will study the type of economic transformation that Pakistan’s economy requires to 
sustain high growth. Pakistan’s transformation during the last three decades has not been as 
fast or as intense as that of the successful Asian economies. If Pakistan is to step up and 
maintain its growth rate, it needs to accelerate its structural transformation and improvements in 
the quality and diversification of its exports. The TA will require about 36 person-months of 
international consulting. 
 
2.  The  Center  for  International  Development  (CID),  John  F.  Kennedy  School  of 
Government, Harvard University, will prepare four papers on Competitiveness and Structural 
Transformation in Pakistan in close consultation with the Central and West Asia Department 
(CWRD) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). All four papers will be produced by a team of 
economists with expertise in growth and development issues, and knowledge of the Pakistan 
economy.  
 
3.  The  first  paper  will  map  Pakistan’s  product  space  following  the  methodology  in 
Hausmann and Klinger and Hidalgo et al. (Appendix 4, A).1 Economic structure—in terms of 
what a country produces, how it produces it, and what it exports—matters for the country’s 
growth. Whether a country sustains an upward trajectory or grows slowly depends on whether it 
moves  into  activities  that  create  opportunities  for  productivity  gains;  and,  when  these  are 
exhausted, whether the country can shift once more to other new, more productive activities. 
Using a new methodology and software developed by CID, it is possible to map what a country 
produces  and  how  close—or  far—the  representation  of  this  basket  is  from  those  of  other 
countries.  In  this  way,  the  possibilities  for  Pakistan  to  diversify  production  and  increase 
productivity can be analyzed in light of its technological and social capabilities. The analysis will 
assess Pakistan vis-à-vis other countries in Asia. The paper will be submitted to the ADB officer 
in charge of the project by September 2008. 
 
4.  The second paper is on export quality, following the methodology in Hausmann et al. 
(Appendix 4, B). 2 A strong empirical relationship exists between the level of income of a country 
and a measure of export sophistication recently developed by CID. One implication of this 
relationship is that, as the process of development takes place, countries change their export 
package.  This is also a reflection of structural transformation. Therefore, an in-depth analysis, 
at a highly disaggregated level, of Pakistan’s export structure will provide key information for 
assessing the speed and direction of the country’s transformation. The analysis will assess 
Pakistan vis-à-vis other countries in Asia. The paper will be submitted to the ADB officer in 
charge of the project by September 2008. 
 
5.   The third paper is a growth diagnostics analysis aimed at assessing the impediments to 
structural transformation in Pakistan. This paper will follow the methodology in Hausmann et al. 
                                                 
1 Hausmann, Ricardo, and Bailey Klinger. 2006. Structural transformation and patterns of comparative advantage in 
the product space. Washington, DC: John F. Kennedy School of Government.  
   Available: http://idbdocs.iadb.org/wsdocs/getdocument.aspx?docnum=773109 
Hidalgo, C., B. Klinger, A-L Barabasi, and R. Hausmann. 2007. The Product Space Conditions the Development of 
Nations. Science 317: 482–487. 
2  Hausmann, Ricardo, Jason Hwang, and Dani Rodrik. 2005. What you export matters. Washington, DC: John F. 
Kennedy School of Government. Available: http://ksgnotes1.harvard.edu/Research/wpaper.nsf/rwp/RWP05-063

10  Appendix 3 
 
(Appendix 4, C).3 The paper will be submitted to the ADB officer in charge of the project by 
March 2009. 
 
6.  Using the analysis of the first three papers, the fourth paper will propose a plan for 
industrial development, because structural transformation is the result of purposeful action. It is 
not automatic, in other words, but must be induced through policy (Appendix 4, D). A well-
developed plan, in the form of industrial policy that involves strategic collaboration between 
public and private sectors, is an important tool. Industrial policy is not about picking the winners. 
Identification of the product space, along the lines of the new literature, is the way to identify 
sectors with potential for a country’s development. The idea is based on the concept that a 
country has given capabilities that allow it to produce certain products. These capabilities should 
also allow it to produce other similar goods, because they require similar capabilities. Jumping 
successfully from the production of less sophisticated products—textiles, for example—into the 
production of more sophisticated ones—electronics and automobiles—is not simply a matter of 
training more engineers and scientists. As the successful Asian countries have shown, an 
economy must master each step along the way. If this is not done, the effort at industrial 
upgrading will be an exercise in futility. The draft of the paper will be submitted to the ADB 
officer in charge of the project by June 2009. The final version will be submitted by September 
2009. 
 
7.  In  conjunction  with  the  ADB  officer  responsible  for  the  project,  the  consultant  will 
participate in the dissemination of the study’s results in Pakistan and in ADB headquarters in 
Manila. To address concerns about how the legal and policy environment in Pakistan might 
affect the development and implementation of a realistic industrialization plan, the TA envisions 
different presentations tailored to the three main stakeholders—the Government, policy makers, 
and  entrepreneurs.  Each  plays  a  different  and  important  role.  The  Government  must 
demonstrate the political will to undertake structural transformation, policy makers must take 
part in designing the plan and internalize it, and entrepreneurs will be responsible for carrying it 
out effectively. CID will also present the findings of the TA in Manila at the conclusion of the 
project. Travel to Pakistan and to ADB’s headquarters in Manila will be coordinated and agreed 
upon with ADB’s officer in charge of the project. 
 
A.  International Experts (36 person-months, 5 consultants and 2 research assistants) 
 
1.   Team Leader (6 person-months) 
 
8.  The  team  leader  will  be  an  expert  in  economic  development  with  an  extensive 
publication record in economic development issues. He will specialize in growth and structural 
transformation, and will be an expert in CID’s methodologies on growth diagnostics, product 
space, export sophistication, and industrial policy (Appendix 4). 
 
9.  The team leader will be responsible for carrying out the following activities: 
 
(i)   drafting the four components of the study, as well as an executive summary; 
(ii)   delivering all reports and outputs in appropriate format; 
(iii)   providing advisory services to CWRD; 
(iv)   coordinating the team’s work and communicating with ADB; 
(v)   traveling to Pakistan and Manila, as agreed with ADB’s project leader;

Government, Harvard University. Available: http://ksghome.harvard.edu/~drodrik/barcelonafinalmarch2005.pdf.

Appendix 3  11 
(vi)    delivering  two  lectures  in  Pakistan  on  the  growth  diagnostics  methodology, 
product  space,  export  sophistication,  and  industrial  policy,  with  timing  and 
locations agreed upon with ADB; 
(vii)   delivering  one  lecture  in  ADB  headquarters  on  the  growth  diagnostics 
methodology, product space, export sophistication, and industrial policy; 
(viii)   disseminating the findings of the study in Pakistan and ADB headquarters, as 
agreed with the project leader; and  
(ix)   providing ADB with copies of all primary data as well as data transformations, 
graphs, etc. used in the project. 
 
2.   Economic Development Specialist (6 person-months; 4 consultants) 
 
10.  The economic development specialists will be expert in economic development with an 
extensive publication record in economic development issues. The specialists will be familiar 
with the growth diagnostics methodology, product space, export sophistication, and industrial 
policy  literature  (Appendix  4).  At  least  one  of  the  four  development  specialists  will  be 
knowledgeable about Pakistan’s economy. 
 
11.  The economic development specialists will be primarily responsible for carrying out the 
following activities: 
 
(i)   delivering major outputs; 
(ii)   providing advisory services to CWRD; 
(iii)   assisting the team leader; and 
(iv)   traveling  to  Pakistan  and  Manila,  as  agreed  with  ADB’s  project  leader,  if 
necessary. 
 
3.   Research Assistants (3 person months; 2 research assistants) 
 
12.  The qualifications of the research assistants will be at the level of graduate-student 
equivalent. They will be responsible for carrying out the following activities: 
 
  (i)   collecting, processing, and graphing data; and 
(ii)   assisting the team leader and economic development specialists in all aspects of 
the project 
 
B.  Output 
 
13.  The final report will contain a detailed analysis of Pakistan’s possibilities of economic 
transformation during the next decade, emphasizing policy options. The report will have four 
parts (Appendix 4): (i) growth diagnostics, (ii) analysis of product space, (iii) analysis of export 
sophistication, and (iv) industrial policy plan.

12   Appendix 4 
 
 
OUTLINE OF THE FINAL REPORT 
 
1.  The  final  report  will  consists  of  four  parts.  This  appendix  details  the  analysis  to  be 
undertaken in each of the four parts. 
 
A.  Pakistan’s Product Space 
 
2.  Developing new activities and products is not easy for most developing countries. Lack of 
markets and coordination problems can create insurmountable difficulties. For this reason, new 
activities are rarely created in a vacuum, as their development has to take place in the context of 
the existing capabilities, which are useful to the extent that they are similar to those of the new 
products and activities. However, the degree of similarity of capabilities might vary between any 
pair of activities. For example, a country that has developed capability, infrastructure, regulatory 
framework, trained labor force, and knowledge in the production of garments might be in a position 
to develop a shoe industry. However, these capabilities are unlikely to be very useful in developing 
a new steel industry. Capabilities are specific to each activity.  
 
3.  For this reason, one can think of products as trees in the forest—i.e., the product space—
and being at some distance from each other in terms of capabilities. Firms are monkeys that live on 
trees. The distance between the trees reflects the similarity of the required capabilities. In general, 
it is easier for new activities to develop close to the areas where monkeys already live, since they 
will require similar capabilities. Producing very different new products—i.e., at larger distance—
requires capabilities that the monkeys—i.e., firms—do not possess. 
 
4.  Hausmann  and  Klinger  and  Hidalgo  et  al.  have  proposed  a  measure  of  the  distance 
between products. 1 It is based on the fact that if similar capabilities, infrastructure, and technology, 
for example, are needed to produce two different products, this would be revealed in the fact that 
countries that are good at one are also good at producing the other. This idea of “proximity”—the 
ability of a country to produce a product depends on its ability to produce similar products—allows 
the authors to “map the space” of products in the world.2 What are some characteristics of the 
forest, or product space? First, there is a high degree of heterogeneity, with a core and a periphery. 
Second, some parts of the forest have trees (products) with many monkeys (firms), while other 
parts contain few. This implies that the development of comparative advantage in new products is 
strongly affected by the distance between the products being currently produced—i.e., a function of 
the existing comparative advantage—and the potential new ones. In the authors’ words, “monkeys 
tend to jump short distances.” The key to progressing in terms of sophistication is to position the 
country in a well connected part of the forest where it is easier to move to other products. 
 
5.  This research shows that the way countries develop comparative advantage is far from 
random. Some developing countries produce on the periphery of the product space, with few 
opportunities for diversification; others have developed capabilities that are easy to deploy in a 
wide range of products, creating a path to convergence. Progress is very slow in the area of the 
forest with few trees or firms. The probability of jumping to a new tree is strongly affected by how 
far it is from the ones now occupied. Also, the average distance to the trees eventually occupied is 
                                                 
1  Hausmann, Ricardo, and Bailey Klinger. 2006. Structural Transformation and Patterns of Comparative Advantage in 
the Product Space. Washington, DC: John F. Kennedy School of Government.  
   Available: http://idbdocs.iadb.org/wsdocs/getdocument.aspx?docnum=773109 
Hidalgo, C.A., B. Klinger, A-L Barabasi, and R. Hausmann. 2007. The Product Space Conditions the Development of 
Nations. Science 317: 482–487. 
2  Strictly speaking, the proximity between two products is the minimum of the pairwise conditional probability of a 
country exporting a good, given that it exports another one.

Appendix 4  13 
much smaller than the distance to a randomly chosen tree. Moreover, the position of a country in 
the forest at a point in time is a good predictor of how quickly the country upgrades. Evidence 
indicates that this is not an easy process and that using the existing capabilities to develop new 
products is  not  automatic.  In  fact,  when  monkeys  jump  to  new  trees—or  firms  jump  to new 
products—they land on the lower branches of the tree. Then, they move up more easily. This 
means that once a firm can start developing a new activity, it is easier to tackle coordination 
failures  and  gain  the  specific  knowledge  required.  Still,  whenever  a  firm  moves  toward  new 
products, it has to start producing without the required capabilities, and this can be done only at 
lower qualities. For this reason, moving within products is easier and more feasible than moving 
between products. 
 
B.  Exports and Structural Transformation in Pakistan 
 
6.  In conventional trade theory, countries export products that are more intensive in the factors 
in which they are relatively abundant. As countries develop, they accumulate factors of production 
at different rates, and the products that countries produce and export become more intensive in 
these  factors.  In  this  theory,  the  pattern  of  specialization  is  uniquely  determined  by  factor 
endowments, in the sense that, independently of initial conditions, the economy converges to a 
pattern of specialization that can be fully explained by the economy’s factor endowments. At the 
other extreme of the theoretical spectrum, some new trade theory models treat productivity growth 
as the result of learning by doing, and assume away factor endowments as a determinant of 
comparative advantage (e.g., Krugman).3 Here, the pattern of specialization cannot be determined 
independently of initial conditions and history. In these circumstances, real as well as monetary 
shocks become important, as they can influence the pattern of trade specialization. Industrial policy 
also  becomes  important  in  acquiring  new  comparative  advantage,  independently  of  factor 
endowments. 
 
7.  In  recent  work,  Hausmann  et  al.  have  argued  that  specialization  patterns  are  partly 
indeterminate, and may be shaped by idiosyncratic elements.4  They have shown that there is a 
strong relationship between the level of income of a country and the measure of the sophistication 
of exports that the authors construct. One implication of this relationship is that countries change 
their export package as they develop—they must undergo structural transformation. Structural 
transformation appears to be reflected in the improvements in quality and diversification of a 
country’s exports. This implies that the range of goods that an economy ends up producing and 
exporting changes in time. It is also important to note that for the standard theory of comparative 
costs, the transition from the production and export of one type of goods into a different one is a 
function of the changing factor endowments, with no role for active policy. The range of goods in 
Hausmann  et  al.’s  model  is  determined,  however,  not  just  by  factor  endowments,  but  is  a 
complicated process that is determined by the number of entrepreneurs that can be stimulated to 
engage in “cost discovery” in the modern sectors of the economy. The key and primary source of 
international gains is international learning, leading to technical progress and increased labor 
productivity.  However,  upgrading  and  diversification  will  not  occur  automatically;  they  require 
proactive measures. The cost of discovery is the uncertainty that an entrepreneur faces when 
producing a good for the first time in a developing economy. Even when production uses a 
standard technology, the institutional reality of many developing countries requires a substantial 
degree of adaptation. Therefore, an entrepreneur will explore the underlying cost structure of the 
                                                 
3  Krugman, Paul. 1987. The Narrow Moving Band, the Dutch Disease, and the Competitiveness Consequences of Mrs. 
Thatcher: Notes on Trade in the Presence of Dynamic Scale Economies. Journal of Development Economics, 27 
October: 41–55. 
4  Hausmann, Ricardo, Jason Hwang, and Dani Rodrik. 2005. What You Export Matters. Washington, DC: John F. 
Kennedy School of Government. Available: http://ksgnotes1.harvard.edu/Research/wpaper.nsf/rwp/RWP05-063

14  Appendix 4 
 
economy. This is a process that entails considerable positive externalities for other entrepreneurs 
because if the investment is successful, others will follow and emulate the incumbent. In this way, 
the private returns to the first entrepreneur are socialized. If the first entrepreneur fails, however, 
his cost remains private. The “knowledge externality” implies, therefore, that investment levels in 
cost discovery are suboptimal, unless the industry or the government finds some way to internalize 
the externality. 
 
8.  Thus,  the  mix  of  goods  that  a  country  produces  and  exports  might  have  important 
implications for economic growth. Not all goods are alike in terms of their consequences for 
economic performance. Specializing in some products will bring faster growth than specializing in 
others. In other words, exports can be seen both as a tool of development and as a test of a 
country’s success. In this framework, the authors argue, government policy has a potentially 
important positive role to play in shaping the production structure. The authors show that countries 
that latch on to a set of higher-quality goods tend to perform better. 
 
9.  Hausmann and Rodrik also note that countries’ capabilities are specific to each activity. 5 
They also point out the paradox that countries sometimes do not generate potential exports, even 
those these products seem similar to their current export products, or are manufactured and 
exported by countries that seem to have similar endowments to theirs. For example, they note that 
Pakistan exports soccer balls but not hats, while Bangladesh does the opposite. An in-depth 
understanding of Pakistan’s export structure is fundamental to understanding its prospects for 
structural transformation. 
 
C.  Growth Diagnostics in Pakistan 
 
10.  To pinpoint which reforms can deliver the best results and put a country on the path of 
sustained growth, Hausmann et al. advocate setting reform priorities based on the size of their 
direct effects.6 The idea behind this strategy is that it is best to focus on the reforms whose direct 
effects are expected to be significant, because (i) the full list of requisite reforms is unknowable or 
impractical; and (ii) figuring out the second-best interactions across markets—i.e., the possibility 
that distortions interact with each other, with the possibility that the reduction in one distortion will 
end up producing a welfare loss—is a nearly impossible task. Therefore, they advise policy makers 
to go for the reforms that alleviate the most binding constraints and, hence, produce the biggest 
impact—i.e, focus on the bottlenecks directly. Hausmann et al.’s methodology is based on a 
decision tree. They argue that in a low-income country, economic activity must be constrained by 
at least one of two factors: (i) the cost of finance is too high, and/or (ii) the private return to 
investment  is  too  low.  They  propose  following  a  decision-tree  methodology  that  takes  the 
researcher through different branches of the tree to determine the relevant binding constraints. 
 
11.  The  Hausmann  et  al.  methodology  is  best  applied  when  the  objective  is  to  alleviate 
constraints to ignite or stimulate growth. This is not exactly the case in Pakistan, where the 
objective is to sustain growth. Therefore, although important tenets of the methodology are valid— 
asking whether a zero growth rate can be increased is not different, conceptually, from asking 
whether a positive rate can be increased—the exercise will require modifications. Sustaining long-
term  growth  in  developing  countries  requires  policies  that  reduce  boom–bust  cycles.  What 
differentiates successful from unsuccessful countries is the ability of the former to reduce the 
                                                 
5  Hausmann, Ricardo, and Dani Rodrik. 2006. Doomed to Choose: Industrial Policy as predicament. Washington, DC: 
John  F.  Kennedy School of Government. Available: http://ksghome.harvard.edu/~drodrik/doomed.pdf. 
6  Hausman, Ricardo, Dani Rodrik and Andres Velasco. 2005. Growth Diagnostics. Washington, DC: John F. Kennedy 
School of Government, Harvard University.  
Available:  http://ksghome.harvard.edu/~drodrik/barcelonafinalmarch2005.pdf.

Appendix 4  15 
volatility of growth, which reflects decisive responses to shocks, and macroeconomic policies that 
reduce vulnerabilities, and, hence, the costs of shocks. 
 
D.  Industrial Policy as a Central Part of Pakistan’s Development Strategy 
 
12.  Upgrading a country’s production and export structures does not happen without a well-
thought out and crafted push. Structural transformation in the successful Asian economies did not 
come naturally or easily. Although it is common to describe the transformation of the East Asian 
economies as a shift from garments into electronics and automobiles, it was a much more complex, 
painstaking process that entailed (i) carefully identifying products that the country could produce 
profitably by using the existing capabilities, (ii) learning how to use new inputs and methods of 
production, and (iii) exploring new activities that required new capabilities. In a world where agents 
have  to  explore,  learn,  and  adapt  to  an  unfolding  and  unpredictable  environment,  economic 
modernization is hardly preordained. Pakistan has achieved a technological level that allows it to 
manufacture nuclear weapons, while Singapore lacks that particular technology. This, however, is 
no guarantee that Pakistan can undergo successful structural transformation. The capabilities and 
institutions needed to develop a broad-based and sophisticated manufacturing sector that employs 
millions of workers are different from those required to be able to make nuclear weapons. While 
both undertakings call for political will, the latter requires the mobilization and coordination of a 
much  wider  group  of  participants  in  society,  within  the  context  of  a  market  economy  where 
globalization, fast technical change, competition, and the demand question of what consumers 
want, are the rules the game. Singaporean companies understand this.  
 
13.  The  structural  transformation  of  the  successful  Asian  economies  was  the  result  of 
purposeful action that often took the form of industrial policy programs.7 What is industrial policy? 
Far from being interpreted as an exercise in what modern parlance might call picking the winners, it 
is an exercise in coordinating different activities between the public and private sectors with a view 
to identifying market failures that impede structural transformation. It is also a process of eliciting 
information on significant externalities, and about the constraints that exist, and the opportunities 
that are available. This requires strategic collaboration between public and private sectors, and the 
development of the appropriate institutions for change. It applies to agriculture and services as well 
as industry. 
 
14.  Why industrial policy? Markets alone are likely to provide too few of the incentives and the 
demand for new activities that are necessary to transform the economy. There is little economic 
determinism in development—countries do not follow a homogeneous, predetermined trajectory—
and that there is a substantial role for policy. For example, many projects require simultaneous 
investments  to  be  viable;  it  will  be  difficult  to  build  a  hotel  if  transportation  infrastructure  is 
inadequate.  The  coordination  of  investment  decisions  requires  a  signaling  device  to  transmit 
information  about  present  plans  and  future  conditions.  Uncertainty  arising  from  a  lack  of 
information  and  communication—one  decision  maker  having  no  way  to  know  the  concurrent 
decisions and plans of others—complicates things. If this uncertainty is sufficiently great, it might 
inhibit investment decisions and arrest growth. 
 
                                                 
7  Hausmann, Ricardo, and Dani Rodrik. 2006. Doomed to Choose: Industrial Policy as Predicament. Washington, DC: 
John F. Kennedy School of Government. Available: http://ksghome.harvard.edu/~drodrik/doomed.pdf. 
Rodrik, Dani. 2004. Industrial Policy for the Twenty-First Century. Washington, DC: John F. Kennedy School of 
Government. Available: http://ksghome.harvard.edu/~drodrik/UNIDOSep.pdf 
Rodrik, Dani. 2006. Industrial Development: Stylized Facts and Policies. Washington, DC: John F. Kennedy School of 
Government. Available: http://ksghome.harvard.edu/~drodrik/industrial%20Development.pdf

16  Appendix 4 
 
15.  Many developing countries have adopted industrial policies in an attempt to accelerate 
industrialization and economic growth. The results have been mixed, judging by the wide range of 
performance achieved under similar policies. The effectiveness of these policies is a matter of 
controversy. Views differ on whether they made any difference, and if they did, whether it was 
positive or negative.8 This is the case even though observers and policy makers alike have amply 
documented  the  role  of  industrial  policy  in  fostering  swift  industrialization  in  East  Asia.9 An 
important reason for this state of affairs is a lack of consensus on the key issue of how and under 
what conditions industrial policy can significantly alter the rate of capital accumulation and growth.  
 
16.  The  successful  policy  interventions  geared  toward  accelerating  the  transition  between 
different patterns of specialization is the basis for Rodrik’s 1994 interpretation of how the Republic 
of Korea and Taipei,China became rich.10 During these transitions, old comparative advantages 
were eroded while new ones slowly emerged. Market incentives alone would have been unable to 
move the economy to a faster growth path. Rodrik argued that, more than their export orientation, 
the distinguishing features of these growth experiences was the sharp and sustained increase in 
their  investment  rates  in  the  early  1960s.  Through  an  array  of  government  interventions,  by 
subsidizing  and  coordinating  investment  decisions,  government  policy  was  successful  in 
reallocating resources toward modern capital-intensive industries. With increasing returns in these 
activities, this reallocation raised the rate of return on capital, and pushed the economy into a fast 
growth path. Outward orientation followed because the higher investment rates increased the 
demand for imported capital goods. The relatively high level of skills of the labor force in both 
countries was a condition for the success of the industrial policy. 
 
17.  One important lesson that Pakistan can learn from the successful Asian economies is how 
to develop an appropriate industrial policy program that addresses (i) how the country can develop 
a culture of cooperation between the public and the private sector, and (ii) which private sector 
agents  should  be  consulted  first.  Other  questions  need  answers  as  well.  Since  structural 
transformation  is  also  about  fostering  competition,  what  sector-specific  reforms  should  be 
considered? Since structural transformation entails substantial labor reallocation and imbalances 
across  sectors,  how  are  these  changes  and  their  implications  going  to  be  managed?  What 
complementary inputs to the market can the public sector provide? How should public spending on 
infrastructure  and  training  be  prioritized?  What  foreign  firms  should  be  targeted  by  agencies 
promoting foreign direct investment? Further, given Pakistan’s employment problem, what role 
could industrial policy have in improving the situation? 
 
18.  What does it take for industrial policy to succeed? It is impossible to provide a recipe, but 
the willingness of the government to monitor the results and change its policies, as needed, 
appears to be a key ingredient. Many industrial policy successes are the outcome of programs that 
produced poor results at first. Governments had to fine-tune their efforts in light of what they had 
learned. A government that is too involved in the industry cannot do this effectively, because the 
current beneficiaries of the failed policies would tend to block the changes. However, a government 
that simply watches from afar, and keeps firms at arms' length, does not accumulate the evidence 
it must use to be effective. Rodrik argues that the basic elements of the institutional architecture for 
industrial policy are (i) political leadership at the top, (ii) coordination and deliberation councils, and 
                                                 
8  Pack, Howard, and Kamal Sagi. 2006. Is There a Case for Industrial Policy? A Critical Survey. World Bank Research 
Observer, vol. 21: 267–297. 
9  Amsden, Alice. 1989. Asia’s Next Giant: South Korea and Late Industrialization. New York: Oxford University Press; 
and Wage, Robert. 1990. Governing the Market: Economic Theory and the Role of Government in East Asian 
Industrialization. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. 
10 Rodrik, Dani. 1994. Getting Interventions Right: How South Korea and Taiwan Grew Richer. NBER Working Paper 
No. 4964.

Appendix 4  17 
(iii) mechanisms of transparency and accountability.11 In the final analysis, it is fundamental that 
the main stakeholders of this process be simultaneously involved. These are the Government, 
policy makers, and entrepreneurs. Each plays a key role in the design and implementation of a 
successful industrial policy program. While the Government must show political commitment to 
structural transformation, policy makers will have to design the program, and entrepreneurs will 
have  to  implement  it.  The  key  to  a  successful  transformation  of  Pakistan’s  economy  lies  in 
embedding  private  initiative  in  a  framework  of  public  action  that  encourages  restructuring, 
diversification, and technological dynamism, beyond what market forces on their own are capable 
of generating. 
 
                                                 
11 Rodrik proposes 10 design principles for the formulation of industrial policy: (i) incentives should be provided only to 
new activities; (ii) benchmarks for success and failure should be clear; (iii) a sunset clause must be built in; (iv) public 
support must target activities, not sectors; (v) activities that are subsidized must have the clear potential of providing 
spillover and demonstration effects; (vi) authority for carrying out industrial policies must be vested in agencies with 
demonstrated competence; (vii) implementing agencies must be monitored closely by a principal with a clear stake in 
the outcomes, and who has political authority at the highest level; (viii) agencies carrying out promotion must maintain 
channels of communication with the private sector; (ix) optimally, mistakes that result in “picking the losers” will occur; 
and (x) promotional activities need to have the capacity to renew themselves, so that the cycle of discovery becomes 
an ongoing one. (Rodrik, Dani. 2004. Industrial Policy for the Twenty-First Century. Washington, DC. Available: 
http://ksghome.harvard.edu/~drodrik/UNIDOSep.pdf)

metadata.Title: Competitiveness and Structural Transformation in Pakistan
